DOC.HEAD: Soldiers' Families Await Word on Loved Ones; Some Notified of Fatalities
Eds: Leads with six grafs to UPDATE with arrival of soldiers' remains at Dover Air Force Base. Picks up 6th graf, `I would...'.
LaserPhoto JO1
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers' families across the United States hoped for the best, but some got the unwanted word: Their loved ones were among the first fatalities from what the White House called Operation Just Cause. The Pentagon today reported 19 U.S. servicemen killed, 117 wounded and one missing in the attack on Panama. In all, President Bush ordered 9,500 soldiers and Marines into Panama to bolster the 13,000 normally based there. The remains of four soliders arrived this afternoon at Dover Air Force Base, Del., from Kelly Air Force Base in San Antonio, where the wounded from the invasion were taken en route to military hospitals. The bodies in flag-draped caskets were taken off a C-141 Starlifter which landed shortly after 3 p.m. EST. The Delaware base is the site of the Department of Defense's East Coast Port Mortuary. The body of Lt. j.g. John Patrick Connors, 25, of Arlington, Mass., was among the four flown to Dover. Connors, a member of the Navy's special operations unit known as the SEALS, was described as ``fearless,'' by his resident adviser at Worcester Polytechnic Institute, where Connors received a bachelor's in chemical engineering. ``I would come back in the middle of the night from studying and he'd be hanging from the sprinkler pipes going hand over hand,'' said Walter Towner Jr. Also among those killed was 22-year-old Cpl. Ivan D. Perez, who according to his sister, always wanted to be a soldier and passed up a chance to get out of the service last year. ``He wanted to keep going,'' said his 24-year-old sister, Andriana. ``We told him to get out. ... He just really enjoyed being there. Ever since he was a little kid, he wanted to be a soldier.'' The Pawtucket, R.I., family sent him several Christmas cards, including one the day before the invasion. Ten-year-old Miguel, who idolized his big brother, contributed to the last card. ``He drew little soldiers and tanks on the Christmas card,'' his sister said. A soldier from Cincinnati _ James Markwell, a 21-year-old medic _ also was identified by his family as being among those killed. ``This was his first mission,'' said his stepfather, Bill Rouse. ``And I'll bet you he was patching somebody up when he got hit.'' In Leesville, La., residents kept an eye on the television, watching for word on their family members and friends from nearby Fort Polk who were participating in the action against Panamanian Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Mary Oliver, the 14-year-old daughter of an Army sergeant in Panama, spent the day relaying news reports to her mother at work. Mary, who tried to explain the situation to her 10-year-old brother about their father, Sgt. Frank Oliver, said: ``My brother, I don't think he understands. I just keep telling him it must be good, because we haven't heard anything bad.'' Teresa O'Dell, the instructor at a beauty school where several Army wives are in training, said there were a lot of tears when two of her students received calls Wednesday that their husbands were being shipped out to Panama. ``Several of them left here to tell their husbands goodbye,'' O'Dell said. Such rushed, tearful departures also played out in the Spring Lake, N.C., area, a cluster of strip shopping centers, fast-food outlets and trailer parks adjacent to Fort Bragg, home of the Army's 82nd Airborne Division. Sgt. Timothy W. Bolton rushed into his North Carolina home, tossed a few things into a gripsack and turned to his wife, Treva. ``I've got to go,'' he told her. ``I love you. 'Bye.'' A kiss, an embrace, then he was gone, headed back to Fort Bragg, where he boarded a military plane headed to Panama. ``It was quick, but I was one of the lucky ones,'' said Mrs. Bolton, 22. ``I was fortunate he didn't have his bags (on base). If he'd had them with him, I wouldn't have gotten a chance to say goodbye.'' Since her husband's departure, anchormen have become her companions. While she worked at a laundry in a shopping center, she frequently turned to the television to see what new developments were being reported. At Fort Polk, sentries stood guard outside the La Louisiane Recreation Center, where family members received word of the operation. Inside, Army spokesmen said, the mood calmed after the initial announcement Wednesday morning of the move against Noriega. Several women left the center in the afternoon smiling, their children in tow with coloring books in their hands. Army officials didn't allow interviews on the base. ``It's just really high tension now, especially at Christmas time,'' said the Rev. Dennis Hackler, pastor of Cooper Baptist Church. ``They're worried; if things do escalate down there, there'll probably be a lot of people shipped out. It's just kind of a waiting game.''
